APPLIED CATALYSIS A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 Review On the flexibility of the active phase in hydrotreating catalysts Sonja Eijsbouts1 Akzo Nobel Chemicals B)Z, Research Centre Amsterdam, PO Box 37650, 1030 BE Amsterdam, Netherlands Received 18 September 1996; accepted 20 January 1997 Abstract This review deals with the structure of the active phase in sulfidic Co-Mo and Ni-Mo hydrotreating catalysts. Various models describing the catalyst and its interaction with the reaction environment are discussed in the light of the evolution of the active phase during the catalyst life cycle. Special attention is paid to the contribution of M6ssbauer Emission Spectroscopy (MES), Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS), High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM) and Molecular Modeling to the unraveling of the active phase structure. It is concluded that MoS2 sintering and Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS) segregation during the catalyst life cycle force the shift of the actual reaction mechanism from that involving a single site or an ensemble of sites to that of a close cooperation between segregated components. The adsorption of reactants can take place in many different ways, through the heteroatom or through the ring, on the Mo sites as well as on the Co (Ni) sites. The exact state of each active site depends on the reaction environment. If the catalyst is S deficient, the classical adsorption mechanism involving the S vacancy is dominant. With a fully sulfided catalyst surface the adsorption takes place through S-S bonds. The catalyst is a dynamic evolving system adapting itself to its ever changing reaction environment. Each catalyst component fulfills multiple functions in determining the catalyst structure as well as its interaction with the reactant molecules. Keywords: Hydrotreating; Cobalt; Nickel; Molybdenum; Tungsten; Sulfide; Active phase; Active site; Life cycle; Sulfidation; Deactivation; Regeneration; M6ssbauer emission spectroscopy (MES); Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS); High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM); Molecular modeling t E-mail: sonja.s.eijsbouts@amsterdam.chemicals.akzo.nl, tel.: +31 20 6347360; fax: +31 20 6347654. 0926-860X/97/$17.00 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. Pll S0926-860X(97)00035-5 54 S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 1. Introduction In the last ten years, advanced analytical techniques such as M6ssbauer Emission Spectroscopy (MES), Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) and High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM) together with Molecular Modeling have shed new light on the active phase present in sulfidic hydrotreating catalysts. Although a tremendous amount of new information has been acquired, the debates on the local structure of the active sites, the catalytic function of the active phase components and the reaction mechanism remain inconclusive. Different studies clearly contradict each other and little effort is made to explain the disparities. Conclusions are drawn neglecting the limitations of the analytical techniques or underestimating the influence of the sample prepara- tion and treatment prior to analysis. This review is focused on the structure of the active phase in typical Co-Mo/ A1203 and Ni-Mo/AI203 catalysts. To avoid excessive broadening, no attention is paid to the effect of additives (P, F, Ru, etc.). For the same reason, Ni-W/AI203 catalysts and those prepared on other supports than A1203 are not extensively discussed. The terms active site and active phase are used as follows: The active site is the transition metal ion facilitating (through its S vacancies or S ions) the adsorption of the reactant molecule (heterocyclic compound or hydrogen). The active phase is the active site plus the ensemble of transition metal and sulfur ions making this site active. The active phase is situated either on the surface of larger metal sulfide crystallites or, as very small clusters, directly on the support. The present views on the catalyst structure and its developments during the catalyst life are summarized here and in Sections 2 and 3. Sections 4-6 are focused on the interaction of the catalyst with its reaction environment. Molecular Modeling studies are touched upon in Section 6. MES, EXAFS and TEM studies that have helped to form the present views on the active phase structure are discussed in Section 7. The important experimental details and the potential evaluation problems of these techniques are briefly mentioned. Section 8 depicts a number of studies linking successfully the results of different analytical techniques. Section 9 attempts to find a way to combine the results of different techniques in a solid image of the catalyst in its working state. It is aimed to show that the different catalyst models presented in the literature may very well be complementary instead of contradictory. This idea is based on the fact that the catalytic system in question has proved beyond any doubt to be extremely dynamic and flexible. It evolves and restructures during its entire life cycle, starting from the oxidic catalyst preparation, over the sulfidation pretreat- ment and deactivation under reaction conditions, to its return to the oxidic state during the regeneration. It has to adapt to different conditions of temperature, H2 and HzS partial pressures, to different feedstocks as well as to the presence of coke and metal deposits on the catalyst surface. During all these changes, in different states of MoS2 dispersion and C09S8 (Ni3S2, NiS) segregation and with variable S S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 55 content, it keeps its ability to facilitate numerous reactions via many different mechanisms. It is, therefore, reasonable to assume that contradictions between various studies may be partly the result of describing catalysts prepared or used differently. Another source of deviations may be the differences in the sample treatment prior to analysis as well as the exposition of the catalyst to extreme conditions during the analysis. 2. Evolution of the active phase during the catalyst life cycle The structure and dispersion of the active phase change dramatically during the life cycle of a typical A1203 supported Co-Mo (Ni-Mo) hydrotreating catalyst (Fig. 1). Oxidic Co-Mo (Ni-Mo) catalysts usually have a high Mo dispersion (well dispersed MoO3 or polymolybdate phase), with well dispersed CoO (NiO) present in the proximity of Mo [1-9]. Sometimes, fnely dispersed CoMoO4 (NiMoO4) is observed [10-16], a component of the oxidic catalyst with a direct Co-Mo (Ni-Mo) interaction [17,18]. Mo is usually assumed to be bound to the support via-O-A1 bridges [5,19-27]. Crystalline (XRD detectable) MoO> CoO (NiO), Ale(MoO4)3, COA1204 (NiA1204), CoMoO4 (NiMoO4) are present in the oxidic catalysts in very small amounts if at all [10,12,13,15,16,28-30]. During the sulfidation [31-41], finely dispersed MoO3 and CoO (NiO) are transformed into sulfides. A direct interaction between sulfidic Co (Ni) and MoS2 is generated [42-49]. The catalyst consists of well dispersed MoS2, with edges decorated with sulfidic Co (Ni) [42-46,49] (Fig. 2(a) and (b)). Large MoS2 and Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS) crystals are generally absent [38,40,50-57]. Crystalline MoO3 and CoO (NiO) only get sulfided on the surface while the core preserves its oxidic character or gets reduced to metal [26,58]. If present, crystalline A12(MoO4)3, COA1204 (NiA1204), CoMoO4 (NiMoO4), CoO (NiO) and MoO3 do not get (fully) sulfided [16,26,37,38,59-61] under the typical laboratory (gas phase, 673 K, 0.1 MPa, 10% H2S/H2) or commercial (e.g. liquid phase, -4-603 K, :k3.0 MPa, light oil spiked with S compounds such as, e.g. dimethyl disulfide [62-65]) sulfidation conditions. It is sometimes proposed that also a part of the Mo remains incompletely sulfided, maintaining the Mo-O-A1 bridges [5,9-21,24,26,35,66-71] (Fig. 1). These linkages with the support are suggested to be the reason for the high initial MoS2 dispersion [21 ] as well as for the perpendicular position of a part of the MoS2 slabs on the support [19,21,72-74], leading to the formation of MoS2 slabs with truncated edges [20]. The role of the Mo-O-A1 linkages is negligible if the sulfidation is carried out at high temperature or if special preparation routes (e.g. dried catalyst prepared with nitrilo triacetic acid (NTA) [47,56]) are applied. As Mo gets more completely sulfided under the reaction conditions [11,21,36,37,75- 77], MoS2 clusters, no longer linked to the support, can migrate over the A1203 56 S. Catalyst life cycle: (a) Oxidic catalyst - oxidic Mo and Ni (or Co) are bound to A1203; (b) Partly sulfided catalyst - sulfidic Ni (or Co) is no longer linked to A1203, Mo oxysulfide is still bound to A1203; (c) Partly sulfided catalyst - part of Mo is no longer bound to AlaO3; (d) Partly sulfided catalyst - small MoS2 slabs decorated with Ni (or Co) are formed, these slabs are still anchored to A1203; (e) Fully sulfided catalyst - Mo gets completely sulfided so that MoS2 slabs decorated with sulfidic Ni (or Co) become mobile; (f) Deactivation - small MoS2 slabs decorated with sulfidic Ni (or Co) sinter to form larger slabs, stacks and crystals, the edge surface area of these crystals is insufficient to accommodate all of Ni (or Co) so that separate Ni (or Co) sulfide crystals are formed; (g) Regeneration - MoS2 crystals along with some decorating Ni (or Co) sulfide get partly redispersed; (h) Regeneration - large MoS2 crystals get only oxidized on the surface, Ni (or Co) sulfide crystals cannot redisperse on oxidation; (i) Regeneration - small structures get fully oxidized and return nearly to their original state; (j) High temperature sulfidation - Mo gets completely sulfided so rapidly that the intermediate steps can be neglected; (k) NTA preparation route - Ni-Mo-NTA complex gets completely sulfided. No linkages with the support are formed at any stage of the process. surface and sinter [21,52,53,75,77,78]. Large MoSz stacks oriented parallel to the support [20,79,80], seemingly following the contours of the support particles [19,20,74,79,81], are formed. As the MoS2 dispersion decreases, the relative amount of Co (Ni) on the MoS2 edges gets very high [49,57,80,82-87]. Moreover, since Co (Ni) is not likely to be built in the MoS2 matrix, segregation of Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS) takes place [28,57,66,82-84,88-95]. As the segregated sulfides have lower activities than the original mixed phase, the MoS2 sintering and the consecutive Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS) segregation contribute substantially to the overall catalyst deactivation [52,53,75,77,96,97]. Except for large crystals, sulfides of Mo and Co (Ni) are transformed back into oxides during the oxidative regeneration [52,53,96-98] (Fig. 1). During this process, coke is removed and a redispersion of Mo takes place through solid- S. Under typical regeneration conditions, large MoS2 crystals get oxidized only on their surface and their redispersion is incomplete [52,53,101]. The redispersion of CoO (NiO) via solid-solid wetting is not possible [5,101]. More likely is the formation of the inactive Co (Ni) sulfates [96-98,103,105-107], aluminates [99,108] or molybdates [94,109]. Although the regeneration increases the surface exposure of the Co (Ni) and Mo species [105,110] the redistribution is incomplete, leading to a lower dispersion and less intimate contact of the active phase components. This distinguishes the regenerated catalyst from the fresh one and explains its lower activity [91,94,96-98,103,106]. Ni-W catalysts parallel to some extent the behavior of their Co-Mo and Ni-Mo counterparts [75,77,111,112]. Oxidic Ni-W catalysts usually contain finely dis- persed WO3, NiO and sometimes also finely dispersed NiWO4 [111-114]. Incidentally, small amounts of crystalline NiWO4, NiAI204 and/or Alz(WO4)3 can be present [72,111-114]. WO3 interacts strongly with the support presumably through W-O-AI bonds [111-114]. WO3 is more difficult to sulfde than MoO3 [75,77,111-113,115] which makes the catalyst somewhat less susceptible to WS2 sintering [75,77]. Crystalline NiWO4, NiA1204 or A12(WO4)3 cannot be (fully) sulfided [111-113] under typical laboratory or commercial sulfidation conditions (see above). During sulfidation, finely dispersed WO3 and NiO are transformed into sulfides and a direct interaction between sulfidic Ni and W is formed [116]. The sulfidic catalyst contains WS2 in addition to amorphous Ni sulfides, crystalline NiS or Ni3S2 [111,l 12,117] and mixed Ni-W sulfides [111,112,117]. Sulfidic Ni interacts with coordinatively unsaturated W atoms located at the edges of WS2 layers [ 117- 119]. Perhaps less pronounced than in the Mo-based catalysts [75,77,111- 113,115], WS2 sintering and the consecutive NiS (Ni3S2) segregation take place [75,77,120] and contribute to the overall catalyst deactivation. Neither WO3 nor NiO are able to spread on A1203 through solid-solid wetting [101] during the oxidative regeneration. More probable is the formation of crystalline NiWO4, NiAI204 or Alz(WO4)3 [5,101,111,112,121]. However, as the dispersion and morphology changes during deactivation are not too extensive [75,98], usually a good restoration of the activity can be achieved on oxidative regeneration [98]. 3. Catalyst models In the last 25 years, numerous active phase models aiming to explain the synergy between group VI and VIII metals have been presented. While the earliest "monolayer" [2,9,122] and "bi-layer" [1,7] theories are focused on the oxidic precursor of the active phase, the models introduced later describe the structure of the sulfidic catalyst. S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 59 The pseudo-intercalation model [123-126] proposes that Co (Ni) decorates the edges of the MoS2 structures. The more recent "Co-Mo--S" model [57,80,95,127,128] is closely related to the pseudo-intercalation theory. It claims (based on MES and NO Chemisorption (NOC) data) that a unique "Co-Mo-S" phase, with atomically dispersed Co on the MoS2 edges, is responsible for the major part of the catalytic activity. The evidence for the presence of Co (Ni) on the MoS2 edges has been provided also by EXAFS [42,44,46,49,80,129] (Fig. 2(a) and (b)). Strictly spoken, "Co-Mo-S" is not a phase from the physical point of view but rather a collection of different states of the Co local structure [50] (broad range of "Co--Mo-S" MES parameters [50,56]). In addition, the catalyst intrinsic activity depends strongly on the preparation and activation procedure (NTA, high tem- perature sulfidation [47,56,130-134]) and on the support applied (C, SiO2 [47,80,131-134]). This has lead to separate definitions of the so-called "Co- Mo-S-I" and "Co--Mo-S-II" phases [47,80,132]. Parallel, the "Co--Mo--S-I/II" model has later been extended to Ni-Mo (Ni-Mo-S-I/II) and Ni-W (Ni-W-S-IflI) catalysts [42,49,116,129,130,135,136]. According to EXAFS, the Co (Ni) atoms are located at the edges of the MoS2 structure [42-49,80,116,129,130,132], in the same plane as Mo atoms but not in perfect Mo positions [42,44,46,47,49,80,129,130,132] (Fig. 2(a) and (b)). Depending on the structure of the MoS2 edge (10i0 or 1010), Co (Ni) atoms can be coordinated to one or two Mo atoms. The underlying MoS2 structures can have different morphological features (as observed by TEM) [24,31,51- 53,74,82,88-90,120,138-142]. The typical properties of the "Type I" phases are the lower S coordination of Mo and Co (Ni) and the high dispersion of the underlying MoS2, mostly single slabs having maintained their (Mo-O-A1) interactions with the support [47,80,130,132]. The "Type II" phases are fully sulfided, i.e. have higher S coordination of Mo and Co (Ni), and the underlying MoS2 is less disperse, consisting mainly of stacks not linked with the support [47,80,130,132]. "Type II" phases have higher intrinsic activities in thiophene hydrodesulfurization (HDS) than the "Type I" [47,80,130,132]. The apparently decisive role of the Mo-O-A1 interaction in determining the intrinsic activity may provide some additional clues on the structure of the active phase. If the Mo-O-A1 interaction is to affect the electronic state of the Co (Ni) sites on the edges of the MoS2 structures it must be present in their close proximity. If the MoS2 structures are situated edge up, notable effects can be expected only for Co (Ni) ions attached to the Mo directly involved in the Mo--O-A1 interaction or to its direct neighbor. This means that only if the MoS2 structures are very small (e.g. seven Mo atoms per slab) a significant portion of the edges is affected by this interaction with the support. If the MoS2 structures are situated basal up, in the bottom layer, the Mo edge atoms or their direct neighbors must participate in the Mo--O-A1 interaction to affect the Co (Ni) ions attached to the edges of the bottom 60 S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 layer. The Co (Ni) ions on the edges of the upper layers are anyhow unaffected by the Mo linkages with the support. As the MoS2 stacking usually goes parallel with the increase of the stack diameter [52,53,75,77,96,97], the ratio of "Type I" and "II" as well as the total population of the (Type I+II) active sites always decreases on MoS2 sintering. To depict just Type I and II phases seems, however, too static to describe the dynamic changes of the catalyst during its sulfidation and deactivation. TEM [51,53] as well as MES [50,143-145] results indicate strongly that the active phase transforms gradually. The initial state may be described as the "Type I" phase (very small active phase clusters deposited directly on the support). During the catalyst use, the "Type II" (active phase situated on the surface of larger MoS2 crystallites) is slowly formed. As the deactivation proceeds, the catalyst compo- nents reach a highly sintered state with segregated small entities of Co (Ni) sulfides of different stoichiometries. Finally, even large crystals of MoS2 [51,53,75,77,96,97], Co9S8 [57,66,82,88,89,91-93,95,146] (Ni3S2, NiS [28,51,53,84,91,94]) are present. It is well known that with certain preparation procedures (NTA [47,130]) and supports (C or SiO2 [47,80,130,132]), the "Type II" phase is formed directly without the "Type I" intermediate. The synergetic effect in the "Type I and II" structures is often explained by the electron transfer from Co (Ni) to Mo, removing metal-S anti-bonding electrons from Co (Ni) [ 139,140,147-150]. These changes of electron densities on Mo and Co (Ni) sites are suggested to increase the intrinsic activity of the Mo sites [139,148,149] or of the Co (Ni) sites [151]. This electron donation model [139,140,147-151], similarly to the catalyst model based on the formation of ternary sulfides (Chevrel compounds) [152], assumes a strong interaction between Mo and Co (Ni). The theories mentioned so far either consider Co (Ni) as a promoter for MoS2 or at least claim that Co (Ni) and Mo and S are required to obtain the high activity. In contrast to that, there are also models proposing that Co (Ni) is the real active site [ 153-156]. When supported on carbon, Co alone can achieve activities comparable to those of Co-Mo/AlzO3 catalysts [156]. According to MES, the Co local structure in the Co/C catalysts can be identical to that of Co in "Co-Mo-S" [50,143-145,157], corresponding in both cases to a Co sulfide of a special structure different from Co9S8. Essentially the same species, perhaps with a somewhat different particle size and/or ordering, are observed in Co and Co-Mo supported on A1203 and carbon [50,143-145,157]. Moreover, in the case of highly dispersed Co sulfide present in Co/C catalysts at extremely low Co loadings [158], the intrinsic activity is the same as that of Co in "Co-Mo-S" but the structures do not exhibit the "Co-Mo-S" MES spectrum. Also experiments with highly dispersed Co, Ni and Mo sulfides deposited in zeolites show that extremely high activities can be achieved without a real synergetic effect [159-167]. Different representations of a conventional catalyst are then possible, e.g. with "separate" Co (Ni) and Mo sites [ 168,169] cooperating in an ensemble [ 136,170,17 ! ]. Another possibility is that S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 61 MoS2 is just a primary support for the Co active sites (preventing a strong interaction between Co and A1203) while A1203 (secondary support) only ensures a high dispersion of the MoS2 primary support [45,153,154,156,172]. Alternative theories propose that the role of Co (Ni) is simply to increase the structural disorder of the MoS2 active phase [71,82,139,173,174]. No matter what are the active sites, the catalyst activity is then proportional to the MoS2 edge surface area [71,82,139,173,174]. Similarly to changes obtained through chemical etching of MoS2 micro crystals [175], Co (Ni)-induced defects in the MoS2 structure may change the ratio between the so-called RIM (top and bottom layer in an MoS2 stack) and the edge sites in the MoS2 structures [176-179]. Another theory not requiring any direct interaction between Mo and Co (Ni) is the remote control or contact synergy model [180-187] that envisages a close cooperation between two distinct phases (MoS2 and Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS)), with the group VIII metal providing spill-over hydrogen to Mo. The synergy is due to an intimate contact between these two phases without a necessary formation of a mixed "Co(Ni)-Mo-S" like phase. This has been indicated in modeling and kinetic studies [187-190] as well as in experiments where hydrogen spill-over was observed [185,190-195]. Indirect evidence for the contact synergy model is, e.g. the fact that the mixed phases tend to segregate under the reaction conditions [28,49,57,66,82-84,88-95]. Although numerous authors nowadays describe the hydrotreating catalysts using the terms related to the "Co-Mo-S" model, there is also sufficient evidence supporting the contact synergy model, the structural disorder concept as well as the theory considering Co and Ni as the real active sites. 4. Wide field of application Co--Mo and Ni-Mo hydrotreating catalysts are commercially used over a broad range of conditions. Temperatures between 530 and 700 K and Hz partial pressures between 0.5 and 20.0 MPa are feasible. Feedstocks varying from light naphtha to vacuum residue can be treated. The heavier the feedstock, the higher H2 to oil ratio is applied (50-1200 N m3/m3). The H2S concentrations may vary considerably, ranging from under 0.5 to over 10 vol% HeS. Under these conditions, the catalysts are capable to catalyze a large variety of reactions such as HDS, hydrodenitrogenation (HDN), hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), hydrogenation (HYD) and hydrodemetallation (HDMe). Hydrocracking (HC) reactions are catalyzed to a lower extent unless the catalyst contains acidic components. Reactant molecules of varying sizes and chemical properties, from small heterocycles to porphyrines and polyaromatic compounds, can be converted. Exploratory studies show that hydrotreating catalysts are able to facilitate even more exotic reactions such as, for example, hydrodechlorination [196-199] and that they are still active at low He partial pressures and low temperatures [200-204] 62 S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 (e.g. diene hydrogenation and isomerization at 0.1 MPa and 323 K, SO2 hydro- genation at 0.1 MPa and 573-673 K). 5. Interaction between the active phase and reactants As there is no unanimous view on the structure of the active phase the discussions on how the reactant molecules interact with the catalyst surface are largely inconclusive. The adsorption of reactants can in principle take place through the heteroatom (vertically) [205-210] or through the :r electrons of the aromatic ring (horizontally) [205,206,209-213 ] and can occur on the S vacancies [85,86,117,175,203,204,214- 227] or S atoms [151] attached to the Mo sites [85,86,117,168,169,175,203, 204,214-228] as well as to the Co (Ni) sites [49,116,136,155,170,171,191,209, 229-234]. Although a few authors [208] regard the possibility of reactants adsorbing on the MoS2 basal planes, most theories consider the edges of the MoS2 structures, as such or decorated with Co (Ni), as the only sites able to facilitate the reaction. There are many studies advocating the classical S vacancy theory [85,86,117,175,203,204,21 4-227,232]. However, recent molecular modeling cal- culations reveal that the presence of a S vacancy may not be the necessary prerequisite for the reaction [ 151 ] as the adsorption of reactants such as thiophene can also take place through a S-S bond (Fig. 3). There is also experimental evidence for the participation of sites covered by S2- [225] and of surface SH groups [86,216-218] in the HDS reaction. Numerous studies indicate that different active sites are present on the catalyst surface depending on the pretreatment and reaction conditions [188,203,204,223,235-242]. The differences are usually related to the degree of reduction (S deficiency) of the active phase (specifically the MoS2 edge), resulting in different catalyst activities and selectivities [202,204,219,235-238]. It is reasonable to assume that S vacancies are the most important active sites in highly S deficient catalysts while the S-S adsorption mechanism might play a prominent role in fully sulfided catalysts. The mode of adsorption depends also on the reactant surface coverage [209,212,243,244]. A horizontal adsorption involving multiple adsorption sites is envisaged especially if the reactant surface coverage is low and if the catalyst surface is to a large extent S deficient [212,244]. Vertical adsorption is expected at a high reactant surface coverage [212,244]. In general, the interaction with the active phase destabilizes the reactant and makes it prone to further reaction [73,231,245,246]. Besides the S content variations of the active phase, also the MoS2 sintering and Co9Ss (Ni3S2, NiS) segregation during the catalyst deactivation determine which sites are available for reactant adsorption. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 consider the Mo sites as the most important [85,86,117,168,169,175,203,204,214- 228], most commercially used hydrotreating catalysts have Co (Ni) : Mo atomic ratios around 0.4 or even higher. Even at relatively high MoS2 dispersions, the MoS2 edges are likely to be to a great extent occupied by the Co (Ni) atoms [49,233] and the adsorption of reactants on the Co (Ni) sites is therefore very probable [209,229-232,234]. Not only their availability but also, e.g. the higher probability of S vacancy formation on Ni than on Mo [233] and the implications that the affinity of Co (Ni) to adsorb reactant molecules may increase on the electron transfer from Co (Ni) to Mo [155], advocate that the Co (Ni) sites are the real active sites in this type of catalysts. As shown in computer modeling studies (Section 6), these sites are able to interact with, e.g. thiophenic S as well as to generate spill-over H+ ions. Experiments indeed show that, e.g. thiophene attacks the Co-Mo-cyclopentadiene cluster preferentially on the Co atom [ 191 ]. Also the similar intrinsic activity of Ni in Ni-W/C and Ni-Mo/C catalysts indicates that there are essentially the same Ni active sites in both types of catalysts [116]. With MoS2 continuing to sinter during the catalyst deactivation, the high occupation of the MoS2 edges by the Co (Ni) atoms eventually leads to Co9Ss (Ni3S2, NiS) segregation. The consequence of this transformation may be the shift of the preferred reaction mechanism from that involving a single (promoted) site or a few neighboring sites (facilitating adsorption or reactants spill-over) [136,170,171,202,204,219,230,237,247] to that of a close cooperation between two distinct phases (MoS2 and Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS)) with, e.g. the group VIII metal providing spill-over hydrogen to Mo (remote control theory [180-187]). 6. Flexibility of active phase micro clusters: computer modeling approach Despite the enormous development of the computational techniques in the last few years, calculations on the HDS reaction mechanism remain very difficult. This is partly due to the fact that the active phase is still poorly characterized. Already the choice of the active phase clusters (small entities [231,248] or large fragments of the MoS2 lattice [207,208]) and of the reactant is very decisive for the calculation result. Modeling of small MoS2 clusters displays very well what effects the variation of the slab size does have on the structure, strain energies and on the formation of S vacancies [249]. Quantum chemical calculations on small Ni3Sy and Ni4Sy [231 ] and Co-Mo2Sx [248] clusters facilitating thiophene HDS reaction show a large number of possibilities [231,248], with thiophene adsorbing in different modes and the clusters reorganizing significantly upon interaction with thiophene (Fig. 4). Although numerous assumptions must be made, the calculations visualize quite well some of the problems the small active phase clusters may have when adjusting to various steps of the reaction cycle. Most calculations require the cluster to have S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 65 H ic C C H( I ' S Ni Ni 'Ni (~) S H~._H S S (hi H Fig. 4. Adsorption of thiophene on Ni3S2 (redrawn from [231]): (a) Adsorption of thiophene in ,/~1 configuration; (b) Adsorption of thiophene in 7]4 configuration. zero charge, supposing saturation of all valence bonds on the edges of the MoS2 structures (hydridic species on MoS2 surface) [250,251] or at least embedding the cluster in an environment where the cluster charge is compensated for (all x-c~- 66 S. Eijsbouts /Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 scatter calculations [148,151]). Similarly, the real active phase clusters must be capable to compensate for charge differences caused by the reactant adsorption and desorption [191]. The active phase components must thus be able to function in many valence states (e.g. CO1'2'3 Mo3'4'5'6+) or readily compensate for the differences by, e.g. interchanging from S2 to S2- or SH-. This is clearly more difficult in small than in large active phase clusters [249]. The inability of small clusters to compensate for the changes in their valence state may force them to interact with the neighboring entities. This could accelerate the normal thermo- dynamically governed MoS2 sintering process. Another important issue shown in the calculations is the limited accessibility of certain sites for large reactant molecules. Even with molecules capable of adsorption in a number of different ways, a neighboring site [136,170,171,202, 204,219,237,247] may be needed to provide the hydrogen necessary for the reaction and for the regeneration of the active site [ 136,170,171,202,204,219, 237,247]. This suggests that either an active phase cluster size exceeding a certain minimum may be required to provide any catalytic activity at all or isolated sites may have to cooperate. As the surface loadings in commercial catalysts are usually rather high (from below 2 up to over 10 metal atoms per nm2), neighboring catalytic sites capable to cooperate are present in a very close proximity. For small reactants high HDS activities are obtained at extremely low Co ioadings [158], suggesting that in this case the catalytic cycle does not require additional adsorption sites. In the near future, it will be possible to carry out molecular modeling calcula- tions with increasingly complex systems, with large active phase clusters as well as with large reactant molecules, representative for real catalysts and feedstocks. To provide the correct input for the computer modeling, the composition and structure of the active phase must be well described. Studies focused on the characterization of the active phase in the sulfidic catalysts are, therefore, essential. 7. Analytical tools The use of a large variety of advanced analytical techniques is inherent to the fundamental research on sulfidic hydroprocessing catalysts. Chemisorption tech- niques such as Dynamic Oxygen Chemisorption (DOC) ]252-255], CO [92,150,215,234,252,256-259] and NO [25,95,149,150,215,223,234,258-265] Chemisorption (COC and NOC) provide information on the active phase disper- sion [25,92,95,252,256,263] as well as on the type of sites present on the catalyst surface [92,95,149,150,215,223,234,257-262,264,265]. The chemisorption data can be related to the catalyst activity, being that the relationships are usually limited to a family of catalysts [266]. The temperature programmed techniques, Temperature Programmed Sulfidation (TPS) [32-34,36,37,40,41,169,264,267-269], Temperature Programmed Reduc- S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 67 tion (TPR) [11,38,41,65,94,114,117,250,267,269-273] and Temperature Pro- grammed Oxidation (TPO) [32,41,94,96-98,239,270] help to understand the catalyst changes on sulfidation and regeneration. For example, differences in sulfidability, depending on the type of compound and its dispersion, can be visualized [33,34,36,37,40,113,267,268]. The TPS and TPR characteristics can then be related to catalyst activity [274]. Also temperature programmed desorption (TPD) or temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) are sometimes applied [ 168,169,195,264,269,271 ]. While X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) is regularly used for character- ization of sulfidic catalysts [20,22,28,29,39,46,47,60,61,72,91,96-98,105,138, 140,142,163,195,222,240,244,250,252,269,274-282] many other techniques are applied less often, e.g. (in situ) Laser Raman Spectroscopy (LRS) [ 12,13,15,16,60, 130,222,262,282-286], Rutherford Back Scattering (RBS) [39,206], Secondary Ion Mass Spectroscopy (SIMS) [39], Inelastic Neutron Scattering (INS) [287], Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM) [93,288,289], Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) [288], Low Energy Ion Scattering (LEIS) [72], Co and Se metal solid NMR [290,291 ], solid state 95Mo NMR [292], 129Xe NMR [ 161,293-295], 99Mo--/~99Tc Spectroscopy [296], Thermo Vacuum Electrical Conductivity studies [280], Magnetic Susceptibility studies [30,108,149,224] and Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) [68,108,160,213,297-300]. However, in the past ten years, three advanced analytical techniques have acquired a solid position among the tools used for the characterization of sulfidic hydroprocessing catalysts. These techniques are MES, EXAFS and HR-TEM. 7.1. M6ssbauer emission spectroscopy 7.1.1. MES measurements While M6ssbauer Absorption Spectroscopy (MAS) is used for Fe-(Mo) cata- lysts [301-304] MES is primarily applicable for Co-(Mo) catalysts labeled with 57Co. If assumed that Ni and Co are present in similar positions on the MoS2 edges, MES may be also used for 57Co doped Ni-Mo catalysts [135]. After drying and calcination, the samples are usually sulfided in situ in a mixture of HzS and H2 at atmospheric pressure and at 673 K. In principle, the catalyst can undergo any specific treatment before recording its MES spectrum [56,57,134,303-307]. As the exposure of the sulfidic catalysts to air significantly affects the Co atoms [24,56,144,306,308] it is imperative to measure the spectra in special MES in situ cells [ 128,309-312]. As the spectra are temperature dependent, it is essential to measure at a number of different temperatures [57,157,303,313,314] between liquid He and room temperature (Fig. 5). The spectra are fitted with calculated subspectra consisting of Lorentzian shaped lines [56,305,314], by varying the M6ssbauer parameters in a non-linear, iterative minimization routine. 68 S. In between, Co goes through a whole range of different local structures. The MES signal is a product of magnetic and electric effects. It can, therefore, never be translated in terms of a real structure and atomic composition of the active phase [313]. It is a fingerprint, dependent on the pretreatment and measuring conditions, which should be preferably evaluated in series of spectra recorded after various sample pretreatments [50,143,144,305] (Fig. 6a and b). To prove that certain Co phases are identical, their spectral behavior should be identical over the whole temperature range between the liquid He and the room temperature (Fig. 5). Cases are known, e.g. when identical spectra are obtained for two different samples at liquid He and room temperature, while in the intermediate temperature range spectra with different MES parameters are recorded [313]. 7.1.3. Important findings The first MES studies on sulfidic catalysts indicated that the local structure of Co in sulfided Co-Mo/AI203 catalysts is different from those in Co/A1203, CoMo284, Co9Ss, CoS2 and CoSl+x. It was concluded that a special "Co-Mo-S" phase consisting of Co, Mo and S in a MoS2-1ike structure is responsible for this unique MES spectrum [57,80,95,128,314-316]. The catalyst thiophene HDS activity was shown to be proportional to the amount of Co in "Co-Mo-S" [57,80,132,314]. Octahedral Co was proposed to be the only possible precursor for the formation of a "Co-Mo-S" type of Co sulfide [314]. Structures with "Co-Mo-S" MES parameters were observed also in unsupported catalysts [128,314] as well as in catalysts supported on SiO2 and carbon [132,312]. Later MES measurements showed that Mo is not required to obtain the "Co- Mo-S" MES spectrum and that in Co/A1203, Co-Mo/AI203, Co/C and Co-Mo/C, Co sulfide species with a "Co-Mo-S" type QS can be formed (Fig. 6(a) and (b)). The temperature dependence of the "Co-Mo-S" MES spectra is the same for the Co sulfide phase present in Co-Mo/AI203 and Co/C catalysts [157]. The Co sulfide species are thus essentially the same, only the particle size and/or ordering may differ [50,54,143-145,157,317,318]. The value of QS of the Co phase depends on the sulfidation temperature and on the catalyst Co content. Large QS points to the presence of very small Co sulfide entities while small QS is related to large well- ordered Co sulfide particles [50,143,144,318]. Furthermore, it was shown that not only octahedral but also tetrahedral Co can be the precursor for the formation of a "Co-Mo-S" type of Co sulfide [56]. "Co- Mo-S" phases with a similar degree of dispersion can be prepared on A1203, SiO2 and C supports (Fig. 7(a)-(c)), being that the intrinsic activity of the "Co-Mo-S" phase seems the highest on the C support [ 134]. In general, the activities seem to increase with increasing metallic character (decreasing structural oxygen) [131]. To obtain a more complete information on the active phase structure MES is successfully combined with EXAFS [172]. 7.2. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure 7.2.1. EXAFS measurements EXAFS is applicable for all types of hydroprocessing catalysts. For evaluation reasons, the catalysts should be homogeneous and have a high active phase dispersion. The amount of bulk compounds (e.g. large MoS2 or C09Ss (Ni3S2, NiS) crystallites) must be as low as possible. It is very useful to combine EXAFS with, e.g. MES (to better characterize the Co local structure), TEM (to look at the particle size distribution of MoS2 crystallites) or XRD (to detect whether crystal- line compounds such as CoMoO4 or COA1204 are present) [24,47,172,320]. The EXAFS measurements of sulfidic catalysts should be carried out by using cells allowing the in situ sample presulfiding [42,44,45,49,170,321-323], for instance with a mixture of HzS and H2 at atmospheric pressure and at 673 K. After that, the samples are cooled to room temperature under HzS]H2 flow, followed by flushing with He. The EXAFS spectrum is measured in He atmosphere at liquid N2 temperature. It is unclear whether the extremely low temperature during the measurement can in any way modify the catalyst. There are indications that, e.g. the flushing procedure applied can to some extent affect the EXAFS results [49] (Fig. 8). In the case of a Ni-Mo/AI203 catalyst, variations of Ni-S, Ni-Mo and Ni-Ni coordination numbers are observed if He flushing is preceded by 2% HzS/H2 or H2 flushing. The correct evaluation of EXAFS spectra includes the multiple shell fitting in k-space with optimization in r-space and statistical evaluation. A number of different calculation models are used [324-328]. For the analysis of the spectra, phase shifts and back scattering amplitudes from reference compounds are used [42,43,329-336]. Unfortunately, some authors do not carry out the shell fitting at all and use the Fourier transformations of the spectra as a kind of finger print, drawing thus erroneous conclusions or at least loosing a signi- ficant part of the information. Others fail to carry out the statistical evaluation and include in their conclusions contributions whose statistical significance is ques- tionable. 7.2.2. Difficulties with the interpretation of EXAFS results EXAFS is a technique measuring the average size and composition of active phase clusters in the catalyst. It is often tried to combine all the EXAFS parameters S. Such constructed clusters provide a feeling for how the active phase may look like. However, it is necessary to realize that the catalysts are rather heterogeneous and that the metal sulfides are present in clusters of very deviating sizes and compositions [51-53,137,141 ]. For example, a typical Ni-Mo/AI203 catalyst contains molecularly dispersed MoS2 as well as large MoS2 stacks consisting of hundreds of Mo atoms. Sulfidic Ni decorates the MoS2 edges but smaller amounts are also present as Ni3S2, c~- NiMoO4 or even NiA1204, etc. [5,10,12,16,28-30,89]. EXAFS cannot detect the stacking of MoS2 (WS2) [320]. 7.2.3. Important "EXAFS" findings EXAFS is one of the few techniques able to provide information on the interaction between Mo (W) and Co (Ni). EXAFS parameters are, therefore, often used to describe the different "Co(Ni)-Mo(W)-S-I/II" phases [47,49,116,129,130], with Co (Ni) atoms located at the edges of the MoS2 (WS2) structure [42-49,57,80,83,84,95,116,128,127,136,137], in the same plane as Mo (W) atoms but not in perfect Mo (W) positions [42,44,46,49,116,129,130] (Fig. 2(a) and (b)). The constructed active phase clusters help to generate ideas on how the active phase looks like [42,44,46,49,116]. According to EXAFS, in Ni-Mo catalysts supported on C and on A1203, Ni atoms are situated on the top of $4 squares at the MoS2 edges in the Mo plane, in millerite type Ni sites [42,49]. Each Ni atom is coordinated to two Mo atoms at a distance of 2.85 ,~,. A part of Ni atoms is present at neighboring sites on the MoS2 edges [49]. Recently, another structure has been proposed, namely one having a single Ni-Mo coordination and about fourfold Ni-S coordination [136]. The Ni-W-S structure in Ni-W/C catalysts resembles well that of Ni-Mo-S in Ni-Mo/C, being that Ni is coordinated by six S atoms, probably in a trigonal 76 S, Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 prismatic configuration [116], each Ni atom having an interaction with two W atoms at a distance of 2.80 ,~. The WS2 domains consist of 5-14 W atoms. The Co atoms in Co-Mo-S/C have a distorted five- to sixfold coordination, each Co atom having an interaction with two Mo atoms at a distance of 2.80 [43-46]. There is structural similarity between Co sulfide phases in Co/C and Co-Mo/C, indicating that indeed Co may be the actual active site in these catalysts. The MoSz structures consist of 5-8 Mo atoms [44]. Two types of Co sites have been found, one having a single Co-Mo coordination and about fivefold Co-S coordination and an other, less common, having a double Co-Mo coordination and sixfold Co-S coordination [47], the latter being the only site in C supported catalysts. Lower coordination numbers (Co-S (Ni-S) coordination of 4 or 5, in square and tetragonal pyramidal type sites) [80,129,323,338] have also been found. The presence of oxo-molybdenum species, resistant to sulfidation and stabilizing the MoS2 towards growth has been indicated [320]. Spreading of MoO3 on AIzO3 through solid-solid wetting has been confirmed [23]. Special preparation routes (e.g. involving citric acid or NTA) have been shown to affect the MoS2 dispersion and the local structure of Co deposited on the edges of the MoS2 crystallites [47,130,276]. The process of MoS2 (WS2) sintering and Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS) segregation has also been described [75] (Fig. 10(a) and (b)). A fair impression on the MoS2 dispersion can be obtained [320]. The MoS2 clusters consist often of 7 or 8 Mo atoms and are thus roughly 10 A in size [278,320]. To combine the EXAFS data on the Mo-Mo coordination and those on the Mo-support interaction may very well be the best way to get a measure for the MoS2 dispersion [24,44,47,322,337]. (The Mo-support interaction disappears as the MoS2 gets completely sulfided and starts to sinter.) The Mo dispersion calculated from EXAFS is usually higher than what is visualized by TEM [320] or calculated from XRD. This is due to the fact that TEM and XRD detect only larger structures. If the TEM results are corrected for the amount of not visualized highly dispersed MoS2 the dimensions of MoS2 clusters determined by EXAFS and by TEM are roughly the same [51-53]. In the near future, the in situ EXAFS measurements can be carried out at high temperatures and in the presence of reactants such as thiophene and selenophene. This type of measurements may help to provide new information on the interaction of the reactant molecules with the catalyst [339]. 7.3. High resolution transmission electron microscopy 7.3.1. TEM measurements While TEM and HR-TEM instruments are widely available only a few instru- ments [20,21,340,341] (e.g. Delft University of Technology, University of Wisconsin) are equipped for "(pseudo) in situ" measurements which allows catalyst measurements after specific pretreatments. TEM can be applied to all freshly sulfided and spent hydroprocessing catalysts. The sulfidic catalysts are usually powdered and mostly measured directly after being dispersed in alcohols or alkanes and so deposited on a Cu grid coated with a thin carbon layer [342]. The presence of the carbon layer as well as the remains of the solvent on the specimen surface can negatively affect the visibility of the MoS2 (WS2) slabs [51]. A less common alternative consists of embedding the powdered sample in a polymer which must be easy to impregnate and which must not react with the sulfidic catalyst [51,53,342]. If embedded, the polymer must be hardened and after that sections of about 60-100 nm thickness are prepared by ultrami- crotomy. These sections are collected on a water surface and transferred to a slightly etched (Ar plasma) Cu grid and dried. As the sections have a defined 78 S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 thickness (around 60 nm), they are especially useful when using quantitative Electron Dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis or when evaluating the micrographs semi-quantitatively. The (extended) exposure of the samples to air (e.g. when specimen sections are stored in air for a long period of time) results in less sharp images of the MoS2 (WS2) structures (due to slabs destruction caused by MoS2 (WS2) oxidation [24,51,56,144,277,308]). Short exposures have little effect on the quality of the TEM micrographs [24,51,56,144,277,308]. Not cut samples embedded in polymer can be stored for years [51 ]. Except for the visibility of the MoS2 (WS2) structures, the exposure to air can lead to the formation of Co (Ni) sulfates [51,308], compounds extractable in water or in alcohols. Their presence can affect the results of the quantitative EDX analysis [343]. The temperatures during the normal but especially during the "in situ" measurements, monitoring a small area of the specimen, can locally become very high [342,344-346]. This depends on the thermal conductivity of the material studied and on the applied beam energy. Melting of salts, formation of MoS2 from MoS3 (expected to take place above 623 K) [347], formation of fulerene like MoS2 (WS2) structures as well as destruction of zeolite crystals (likely to occur above 823 K) during the measurements have been observed [348]. Many other undesir- able processes and reactions can be envisaged under these conditions. The TEM micrographs are mostly evaluated visually [51-53,137,141,349]. While even very small MoS2 (WS2) structures (above ca. 0.5 nm in diameter) are easy to recognize in the micrographs, Co (Ni) sulfides can be well imaged by TEM only if present as larger crystals (above ca. 2nm in diameter) [52,165,166,295]. Not too much attention should be paid to a few peculiar features of a certain catalyst sample. To obtain a representative picture of the catalyst, a sufficient number of micrographs, visualizing all different types of regions present in the catalyst must be evaluated. All investigated regions should preferably have the same thickness. A semi-quantitative data evaluation is, in principle, possible [51,53,141,349]. The number of visible MoS2 (WS2) stacks, the average number of layers per stack and the average stack length are determined manually. Manual evaluation is still preferable over image analysis, which is only profitable for areas containing separate monolayers of MoS2 (WS2) but is much more elaborate when crossing slabs have to be unraveled or if parallel lines need to be recognized as belonging to one crystal. When using the microtomed catalyst [51,53], the fraction of MoS2 (WS2) invisible in the TEM micrographs can be fully taken into account in the calculation of the real MoS2 (WS2) dispersion [51-53]. (Invisibility is due to improper orientation of the slabs with respect to the electron beam, thickness effects of the catalyst section and to the inability of the microscope to image the smallest MoS2 (WS2) structures.) The semi-quantitative evaluation includes numerous assumptions concerning e.g. the shape of MoS2 (WS2) structures (perfect hexagons vs. truncated edge) [20], S. Eijsbouts /Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 79 the way they are attached to the support (edge vs. basal bonded) [19,20], orientation of slabs to the electron beam [350], TEM information depth, etc. By comparison of the calculated density of the observed MoS2 (WS2) structures with the real Mo (W) content, the fraction of highly dispersed MoS2 (WS2), falling below the TEM detection limit, can be derived and included in the calculation of the overall MoS2 (WS2) dispersion [51-53]. 7.3.2. Problems with the interpretation of TEM results Although the qualitative interpretation of TEM micrographs seems relatively easy the application of TEM results is by no means trouble free. Only in a limited number of TEM studies [51-53] it is recognized explicitly that very small MoS2 (WS2) clusters (seven Mo or W atoms per cluster or less) cannot be imaged. This means that the structures observed by TEM, however well imaged or having particular features, not necessarily have to be representative for the majority of MoS2 (WS2) in the catalysts. An estimate of the non-visualized part of the MoS2 (WS2) (e.g. by EDX) is essential when using the TEM results. There are indications that only a few percent of the total MoS2 are visualized by TEM in sulfided commercial Co-Mo catalysts [51]. Although the portion of MoS2 visualized in spent commercial Ni-Mo catalysts is considerably higher [51-53], also here a significant part of Mo is not imaged. This is also the case for metal sulfides present inside the zeolite particles [166,295,351,352]. The determination of the orientation of the MoS2 structures on the support (parallel vs. perpendicular) is possible only in specific cases. With model catalysts (thin layers of MoO3 deposited on thin "y-A1203 films) the perpendicular position of a part of the MoS2 slabs on the support (formation of MoS2 slabs with truncated edges) is indicated [20]. MoS2 slabs oriented parallel to the support are sometimes detected when studying the contours of the support particles, e.g. [19,26,79]. However, in most cases there is no indication on the orientation of the structures. 7.3.3. Important findings Unlike other techniques, TEM can visualize the morphology of the MoS2 (WS2) structures, the overall catalyst dispersion and homogeneity as well as the particle size distribution (stacking and length) of the MoS2 (WS2) structures [20,21,24,26,31,51-53,74,79,82,88-90,120,138-142,175,178,252,269,275,283]. Defects in the MoS2 (WS2) structures, e.g. those induced by the Co (Ni) can be imaged [82,176,353,354]. In general, MoS2 dispersion and stacking are associated with the type of promoter (Co vs. Ni) [82,87,138,139,141,355,356], the presence of P [138,357], the type of support (A1203, SiO2, ZrO2, TiO2, NiAI204 etc.) [26,79,140-142,356], the sulfidation conditions [19,20,76,140,283] as well as the degree of catalyst deactivation [51-53,75] (Fig. l l(a)-(c)). MoS2 slabs with truncated edges [20] may be an indication for the perpendicular (edge up) position of a part of the MoS2 slabs on the support. MoS2 slabs apparently following the contours of the support particles may be related to MoS2 stacks oriented parallel to 80 S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 Interesting is also the application of TEM for zeolite containing hydrocracking catalysts where the migration of the active phase from the center to the outer part of the zeolite particles under the reaction conditions can be observed [ 165,166,295,351,352,361,362]. Especially in combination with EDX, a complete description of the distribution of the metal sulfides inside as well as outside the zeolite can be obtained [166,295]. Although the exact position of Co (Ni) on the MoS2 (WS2) edges cannot yet be visualized by TEM [176,363] the future prospects in this direction are very good. As the resolution will further increase it is expected that in the near future atoms can be visualized [340,359] (Fig. 12). 8. Are the results of different analytical techniques complementary? Numerous publications show that the information obtained by a certain tech- nique becomes more valuable when used in combination with other analytical data. A well-known example of linking the results of a number of different techniques is the "Co-Mo-S" model [57,95,128,314,364], using results of MES, NOC, EXAFS and XPS to describe the active phase as well as thiophene HDS to characterize its performance. MES shows that Co is present in a unique local structure and NOC indicates that Co creates new adsorption sites. EXAFS specifies to which neighboring atoms and at what distance is Co coordinated and XPS characterizes the Co valence states. The thiophene HDS activity is used for correlations to MES and NOC parameters. While MES itself is not able to distinguish between the "Co-Mo-S" I and II phases, the combination of EXAFS, MES and thiophene HDS can very well describe the structure and performance of the "Co-Mo-S" I and II phases [24,47]. EXAFS, NOC, LRS and extended activity screening [ 130] can characterize the active phase in Ni-Mo catalysts. Besides the differences in EXAFS data [130], "Ni-Mo-S" I appears less active than "Ni-Mo-S" II in gas phase reactions (quinoline HDN and thiophene HDS) but more active in trickle flow dibenzothio- phene HDS. NOC and LRS seem unable to discriminate between "Ni-Mo-S" I and II phases [130]. RBS, SIMS, XPS and AFM used in combination provide a very complete picture of the sulfidation of MoO3/SiO2 catalysts [39]. AFM is applied to characterize the homogeneity and the MoO3 particle size distribution of the spin coated wafers prior to sulfidation. XPS determines the Mo and S valences. XPS in combination with SIMS detect the presence of oxysulfides. RBS together with XPS provide the S2- Mo and S2- Mo ratios. Similarly, a combination of in situ LRS and TEM [283] describes the sulfidation of MoOa/A1203 and the morphology of the sulfided catalyst. LRS is not only suitable to identify the intermediate species such as oxysulfides and MoS3 but also to obtain indications on the MoS2 crystal size. S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 83 There are, of course, numerous other examples that can be added to this selection. Many of these studies indicate clearly that for a good insight in the continuous changes of the active phase it is essential to measure the catalyst in different stages of a certain treatment instead of characterizing just the oxidic, freshly sulfided or spent catalyst. By combining the information obtained by the different techniques, a more complete representation of the catalyst structure and the possible reaction mechanisms thereon can be obtained. It is not only worth- while to combine the results of different techniques obtained within one study but also those found by other authors, using different catalysts, reaction conditions, analytical instruments, etc. To be able to do so two important assumptions have to be made. Firstly, the catalyst must be considered as a dynamic evolving system adapting itself to its ever changing reaction environment. Secondly, the ability of each catalyst component to fulfill multiple functions in determining the catalyst structure as well as its interaction with the reactant molecules must be taken into account. 9. What is the active phase structure and how does it facilitate reaction? Sulfidic catalysts undergo continuous changes during their life cycle. The catalyst is characterized by a high MoS2 dispersion and a good contact between the active phase components after sulfidation but ends up with a rather sintered MoS2 and a high degree of segregation of the active phase components after extended use. The extent of changes is determined by the reaction conditions the catalyst is exposed to during its use. Therefore, the catalyst and its catalytic action cannot be described by a single model but each stage of the catalyst evolution and each set of reaction conditions has to be described separately. Co (Ni) atoms can have different functions, depending on the overall state of the active phase. When located at the edges of the MoSa structure, they can share electrons with Mo, enhancing the cluster activity and increasing the cluster flexibility to compensate charge differences created during the catalytic reaction. They can also act themselves as the real active sites supported on MoS2. As they do not fit in the MoS2 structure, they, at the same time, increase the structural disorder (and the active surface area) of the MoS2 phase. In a limiting case, as MoS2 continues to sinter, the inability of Co (Ni) to be built in the MoS2 structure leads to the segregation of the Co (Ni) sulfdes, eventually forming crystalline MoS2 and C09S8 (Ni3S2, NiS). Consequently, the preferred reaction mechanism changes from that involving a single site or an ensemble of neighboring sites present in a mixed "Co(Ni)MoS" phase to that of a close cooperation between sites present in separate MoS2 and Co958 (Ni3S2, NiS) phases. The adsorption of reactants can take place in many different ways (through the heteroatom or through the ring) on the Mo sites as well as on the Co (Ni) sites. The exact state of each active site (S content) depends on the reaction environment. In 84 S. Eijsbouts/Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 53-92 cases where the catalyst is S deficient, the classical mechanism involving the S vacancy may be dominant. With a fully sulfided catalyst surface the adsorption can take place through S-S bonds. This representation of the catalyst may not satisfy those seeking for a single well-defined active phase acting according to a specific reaction mechanism. It, however, describes very well the dynamic changes of the sulfidic catalysts during their life cycle and their enormous flexibility to respond to the changes of their reaction environment. On the flexibility of the active phase in hydrotreating catalysts Sonja Eijsbouts 2 Akzo Nobel Chemicals B.V., Research Centre Amsterdam, PO Box 37650, 1030 BE Amsterdam, Netherlands 2 tel.: +31 20 6347360; fax: +31 20 6347654 This review deals with the structure of the active phase in sulfidic CoMo and NiMo hydrotreating catalysts. Various models describing the catalyst and its interaction with the reaction environment are discussed in the light of the evolution of the active phase during the catalyst life cycle. Special attention is paid to the contribution of Mössbauer Emission Spectroscopy (MES), Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS), High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM) and Molecular Modeling to the unraveling of the active phase structure. It is concluded that MoS2 sintering and Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS) segregation during the catalyst life cycle force the shift of the actual reaction mechanism from that involving a single site or an ensemble of sites to that of a close cooperation between segregated components. The adsorption of reactants can take place in many diferent ways, through the heteroatom or through the ring, on the Mo sites as well as on the Co (Ni) sites. The exact state of each active site depends on the reaction environment. If the catalyst is S deficient, the classical adsorption mechanism involving the S vacancy is dominant. With a fully sulfided catalyst surface the adsorption takes place through SS bonds. The catalyst is a dynamic evolving system adapting itself to its ever changing reaction environment. Each catalyst component fulfills multiple functions in determining the catalyst structure as well as its interaction with the reactant molecules. coredata.dc:description: This review deals with the structure of the active phase in sulfidic CoMo and NiMo hydrotreating catalysts. Various models describing the catalyst and its interaction with the reaction environment are discussed in the light of the evolution of the active phase during the catalyst life cycle. Special attention is paid to the contribution of Mössbauer Emission Spectroscopy (MES), Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS), High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HR-TEM) and Molecular Modeling to the unraveling of the active phase structure. It is concluded that MoS2 sintering and Co9S8 (Ni3S2, NiS) segregation during the catalyst life cycle force the shift of the actual reaction mechanism from that involving a single site or an ensemble of sites to that of a close cooperation between segregated components. The adsorption of reactants can take place in many diferent ways, through the heteroatom or through the ring, on the Mo sites as well as on the Co (Ni) sites. The exact state of each active site depends on the reaction environment. If the catalyst is S deficient, the classical adsorption mechanism involving the S vacancy is dominant. With a fully sulfided catalyst surface the adsorption takes place through SS bonds. The catalyst is a dynamic evolving system adapting itself to its ever changing reaction environment. Each catalyst component fulfills multiple functions in determining the catalyst structure as well as its interaction with the reactant molecules.
coredata.dc:title: On the flexibility of the active phase in hydrotreating catalysts
